StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: STORE=libref.template-store] 
          
Specifies the template store.

[For use inside a DEFINE TABLE block] 
          
Preserves the template-type when inheriting it from another table template.

Tip: If you specify an existing template-name without using the NOLIST option, then the template 
is overwritten.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BLANK_DUPS<=ON | OFF | variable>;
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specify whether to suppress the value of a variable from one row to the next, if the value does 
not change based on the formatted value of the variable.

Default: OFF

Syntax: BLANK_INTERNAL_DUPS<=ON | OFF | variable> 

[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to suppress the value of a variable from one row to the next if the value 
does not change according to the raw value of the variable.

Syntax: CHOOSE_FORMAT= COMPROMISE | MAX | MAX_ABS | MIN_MAX

[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Selects a format based on the actual values in the column of the table.

COMPROMISE
looks at all of the values in the column and selects a good compromise format that works well for most 
values, but extreme values might shift to BEST format. 

MAX
selects a format based on the maximum value in the column. Values are all expected to be positive so no 
space is reserved for a minus sign.

MAX_ABS 
selects a format based on the maximum absolute value in the column. The format reserves space for a minus 
sign whether it is needed or not.

MIN_MAX
selects a format based on the minimum and maximum value in the column. The format reserves space for a minus 
sign only where it is actually needed.

Syntax: DATA_FORMAT_OVERRIDE<=ON | OFF | variable>
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN TABLE/DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies which format to use if both a column template and a data component specify a format.

Default: OFF

ON uses the format in the data component.
OFF uses the format in the column template.
variable uses the format of the specified variable.

Syntax: DATANAME=column-name
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the name of the column in the data component to associate with the current column.

Default: By default, ODS associates the current column with a column of the same name in the 
data component.

Syntax: DEF_SPLIT
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies which special characters in headers for generic columns are to be used as split characters.

Syntax: DROP<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to include the column in an output data set.

Default: OFF

Syntax: FLOW<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to wrap the text in the current column if it is too long to fit in the space 
that is provided.

Default: ON if the format width of the column is greater than the column width. OFF if the format 
width of the column is not greater than the column width.

Syntax: FORMAT=format-name <format-width <decimal-width>> | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the format for the column.

Default: 
If you omit the FORMAT= option, then the format that the data component provides is used. 
If the data component does not provide a format, ODS uses one of the following: 
  o BEST8. for integers
  o D12.3 for doubles
  o the length of the variable for character variables

Syntax: FORMAT_NDEC= number | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the number of decimals for the column.

Default: The decimal width that is specified with the FORMAT= column attribute
Range: Number is a whole number from 0 to 32

Syntax: FORMAT_WIDTH=positive-integer | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the format width for the column.

Default: 
If you omit the column attribute FORMAT_WIDTH=, then ODS uses the format specified in the FORMAT= attribute.

Range: 1 to 32 for numeric variables; operating system limit for character variables

Syntax: FUZZ=number | variable 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Supplies a numeric value against which to compare values in the column to eliminate trivial values 
from printing. A number whose absolute value is less than or equal to the FUZZ= value is printed 
as 0. However, the real value of the number is used in any computations based on that number.

Default: This is the smallest representable floating-point number on the computer that you are using.

Syntax: GENERIC<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether the column template can be used by more than one column. Generic columns 
are useful in tables with many similar columns. For example, the table templates for both 
PROC SQL and the DATA step define only two columns: one for character variables and one for 
numeric variables. When a program runs, it determines which column template the data component 
should use for each column.

Default: OFF

Syntax: GLUE=integer | variable 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Influences the places at which ODS splits a table when it creates multiple data panels. ODS creates 
multiple data panels from a table that is too wide to fit in the allotted space. The higher the value 
of GLUE= is, the less likely it is that ODS will split the table between the current column and the 
column to its right.

Default: 1
Range: -1 to 327

Syntax: HEADER=header-specification
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the text for the column header or the name of the header template. header-specification 
is one of the following:

"text"
  specifies the actual text of the header.
  Requirement: text must be enclosed by quotation marks.
header-name
  specifies the name of a header template to use. Create a header template with the DEFINE HEADER 
  statement (see DEFINE HEADER Statement). If header-name is a single-level name, the header template 
  must occur within the current column template.
variable
  specifies the name of a variable declared with the DYNAMIC, MVAR, or NMVAR statement. The value 
  of the variable becomes the column header.
_LABEL_
  Uses the label that is specified in the data component for the column header.

Default: _LABEL_

Syntax: ID<=ON | OFF | variable>
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether the column is an ID column. An ID column is repeated on each data panel. 
(ODS creates multiple data panels when a table is too wide to fit in the allotted space.)

Default: OFF

Syntax: JUST=justification | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the horizontal justification of the format field within the column (and of the header 
if the template for the header does not include JUST=). 

justification is one of the following:

CENTER specifies center justification.
  Alias: C

DEC specifies aligning the values by the decimal point.
  Alias: D

LEFT specifies left justification.
  Alias: L
  
RIGHT specifies right justification.
  Alias: R
  
Default: 
LEFT for columns that contain character values; RIGHT for columns that contain numeric values.

Syntax: JUSTIFY<=ON | OFF | variable>
      
[TABLE/COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE TABLE/COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to justify the format field within the column or to justify the value within 
the column without regard to the format field.

Default: OFF

Syntax: LABEL="text" | variable
      
[TABLE/COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE TABLE/COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies a label for the table/column in the output data set.

Default:
If you omit a label, ODS uses the label that is specified in the data component. If no label 
is specified in the data component, ODS uses the header for the column as the label.

Syntax: MAXIMIZE<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to try to divide the text equally among all lines or to maximize the amount of text 
in each line when the text in the column uses more than one line. For example, if the text spans three 
lines, MAXIMIZE=ON can result in 45% of the text on the first line, 45% of the text on the second line, 
and 10% of the text on the third line. MAXIMIZE=OFF can result in 33% of the text on each line. MAXIMIZE=ON 
can write lines of text that vary greatly in length. MAXIMIZE=OFF can result in using less than the full 
column width.

Default: OFF

Syntax: MERGE<=ON | OFF | variable>
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to merge the current column with the column immediately to its right. When you set 
MERGE=ON for the current column, the data in each row of the column is merged with the data in the same 
row of the next column. ODS applies the format, justification, spacing, and prespacing attributes to each 
column independently. Then, it concatenates the columns. Finally, it applies to the concatenated data all 
the remaining attributes that are specified on the column that does not have MERGE= set.

Default: OFF

Syntax: OPTIONAL<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to delete the current column from the output object if doing so enables all the 
remaining columns to fit in the space that is provided without splitting the table into multiple 
data panels.

Default: OFF

Syntax: OVERLINE<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[TABLE/COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE TABLE/COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to draw a continuous line in the current column above the first table footer 
(or, if there is no table footer, below the last row of the column). The second formatting character 
is used to draw the line. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: PREFORMATTED<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to treat the text as preformatted text. When text is preformatted, ODS honors 
line breaks as well as leading, trailing, and internal spaces. It also displays the text in a 
monospace font.

Default: OFF

Syntax: PRE_MERGE<=ON | OFF | variable>
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to merge the current column with the column immediately to its left. When you set 
PRE_MERGE=ON for the current column, the data in each row of the column is merged with the data in 
the same row of the previous column. ODS applies the format, justification, spacing, and prespacing 
attributes to each column independently. Then, it concatenates the columns. Finally, it applies to 
the concatenated data all the remaining attributes that are specified on the column that does not have PRE_MERGE= set.

Default: OFF

Syntax: PRE_SPACE=non-negative-integer
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the number of blank characters to leave between the current column and the column 
immediately to its left.

Default:
A value in the range that is bounded by the COL_SPACE_MIN and COL_SPACE_MAX table attributes.

Syntax: PRINT<=ON | OFF | variable>
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to print the column. 

Default: ON

Syntax: PRINT_HEADERS<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[TABLE/COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE TABLE/COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to print the table/column headers and any underlining and overlining.

Default: ON

Syntax: SEPARATOR="character" | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies a separator character to append to each value in the column.

Default: None

Syntax: SPACE=positive-integer | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the number of blank characters to leave between the current column and the column 
immediately to its right.

Default:
A value in the range that is bounded by the COL_SPACE_MIN and COL_SPACE_MAX table attributes.

Syntax: STYLE=<style-element-name><[style-attribute-specification(s)]>
      
[TABLE/COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE TABLE/COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the style element and any changes to its attributes to use for the current table/column. 
Neither style-attribute-specification nor style-element-name is required. However, you must use at least one of them.

Note: You can use braces ({ and }) instead of square brackets ([ and ]).   

style-element-name
is the name of the style element to use to display the data in the column. The style element must be part of a style 
that is registered with the Output Delivery System. SAS provides some styles. You can create customized styles with 
PROC TEMPLATE.

style-element-name is either the name of a style element or a variable whose value is a style element.

style-attribute-specification 
describes the style attribute to change. Each style-attribute-specification has this general form: 
  
  style-attribute-name=style-attribute-value

Syntax: TEXT_GRAPHIC= ON | OFF
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies that the text graphic columns be turned off or on when a procedure is going to output 
a graph. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: TEXT_SPLIT="character" | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the split character for the data in the column. The value in the column is broken when it 
reaches that character and continues the value on the next line. The split character itself is not 
part of the data and does not appear in the column.

Default: None

Syntax: UNDERLINE<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
[TABLE/COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE TABLE/COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies whether to draw a continuous line in the current table/column below the table/column header 
(or, if there is no column header, above the first row of the column). The second formatting 
character is used to draw the line.

Default: OFF

Syntax: VARNAME=variable-name | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the name to use for the corresponding variable in an output data set.

Default:
If you omit VARNAME=, then the value of the DATANAME= attribute is used. If you omit DATANAME=, 
then the name of the column is used.

Syntax: VJUST=justification | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the vertical justification for the column. justification is one of the following:

TOP places the first line of text as high as possible.
  Alias: T
CENTER centers the text vertically.
  Alias: C
BOTTOM places the last line of text as low as possible.
  Alias: B

Default: TOP

Syntax: WIDTH=positive-integer | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the width of the column in characters.

Default:
If you omit a width, the format width is used. If the column has no format associated with it, 
ODS uses one of the following widths: 

  o 8 for integers
  o 12 for doubles
  o data length for character variables

Syntax: WIDTH_MAX=positive-integer | variable
      
[COLUMN ATTRIBUTE FOR USE IN DEFINE COLUMN STATEMENT]

Specifies the maximum width allowed for this column. By default, PROC TEMPLATE extends the width 
of the column if the header is wider than the data. The width of the column can be anywhere between 
the values of WIDTH= and WIDTH_MAX=.

Default: The width of the format for the column

Syntax: BALANCE <=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Specifies whether to try to place the same number of columns in each data panel if the entire 
table does not fit in one data panel. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: BYLINE <=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Controls whether BY lines are printed above each BY group in a configuration file, SAS invocation, 
OPTIONS statement, or Systems Options window. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: CENTER <=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Specifies whether to center each data panel independently if the entire table does not fit in the 
space that is provided. 

Default: ON

Syntax: CLASSLEVELS <=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Specifies whether to suppress blanking the value in a column that is marked with the BLANK_DUPS 
column attribute if the value changes in a previous column that is also marked with the BLANK_DUPS 
attribute. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: CONTENTS <=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Specifies whether to place the output object in a table of contents, if you create a table 
of contents. 

Default: ON

Syntax: CONTENTS_LABEL= "string" | variable; 
      
Specifies the label to use for the output object in the contents file, the Results window, 
and the trace record. 

Default:
If the SAS system option LABEL is in effect, the default label is the object's label. If LABEL 
is not in effect, the default label is the object's name.

Syntax: CONTROL=column-name | variable; 
      
Specifies the name of the column whose values provide formatting information about the space before 
each row of the template. The value of CONTROL= should be the name of a column of type character with 
a length equal to 1. 

Values in the Control Column:
Column Control Value    Result
A digit from 1-9        The specified number of blank lines precedes the current row. 
A hyphen (-)            A row of underlining precedes the current row. 
"b" or "B"              ODS tries to insert a panel break if the entire table does not fit in the space that is provided. 

Default: None

Syntax: FOOTER_SPACE=0 | 1 | 2 | variable; 
      
Specifies the number of blank lines to place between the last row of data and the first row of the 
table footer. 

Default: 1

Syntax: FORMCHAR= "string" | variable; 
      
Defines the characters to use as the line-drawing characters in the table. Currently, ODS uses only 
the second of the 20 possible formatting characters. This formatting character is used for underlining 
and overlining. To change the second formatting character, specify both the first and second formatting 
characters. For example, this option assigns the asterisk (*) to the first formatting character, the plus 
sign (+) to the second character, and does not alter the remaining characters: formchar="*+"

Default: The SAS system option FORMCHAR= specifies the default formatting characters.

Syntax: HEADER_SPACE=0 | 1 | 2 | variable; 
      
Specifies the number of blank lines to place between the last row of headers and the first row of data. 
A row of underscores is a header. 

Default: 1

Syntax: PANELS=positive-integer | variable; 
      
Specifies the number of sets of columns to place on a page. If the width of all the columns 
is less than half of the line size, display the data in multiple sets of columns so that rows 
that would otherwise appear on multiple pages appear on the same page.

Syntax: REQUIRED_SPACE=positive-integer | variable; 
      
Specifies the number of lines that must be available on the page in order to print the body of the 
table. The body of the table is the part of the table that contains the data. It does not include 
headers and footers. 

Default: 3

Syntax: TYPE=string | variable; 
      
Specifies special type of SAS data set.

Syntax: USE_FORMAT_DEFAULTS<=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Specifies the source of the values for the format width and the decimal width if they are not specified. 

ON uses the default values, if any, that are associated with the format name. 
OFF uses the PROC TEMPLATE defaults. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: USE_NAME<=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Uses the column name as the column header if neither the column template nor the data component 
specifies a header. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: WRAP<=ON | OFF | variable>; 
      
Specifies whether to split a wide table into multiple data panels, or to wrap each row of the table 
so that an entire row is printed before the next row starts. 

Default: OFF

Syntax: WRAP_SPACE<=ON | OFF | variable> 
      
Specifies whether to double space after the last line of a single row of the table when the row 
is wrapped onto more than one line. 

Default: OFF

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether styles used in an HTML document are used in CSS or LateX style files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that styles are used in CSS or LateX style files.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that styles are not used in CSS or LateX style files.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ACTIVELINKCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color that a link in an HTML document changes to after you click it, but before 
the browser opens that file.

[Syntax: CELLSTYLE expression-1 AS <style-element-name><[style-attribute-specification(s)] ><..., expression-n AS <style-element-name><[style-attribute-specification(s)]>>;] 
          
Part of the CELLSTYLE syntax.
Specifies how to handle leading spaces and line breaks in an HTML document.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Prints text with leading spaces and line breaks, in the same manner as the listing output.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Trims leading spaces and ignores line breaks.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BACKGROUNDCOLOR= color] 
          
Specifies the color of the background of the tables, cells, or graphs.

[Syntax: BACKGROUNDIMAGE="string"] 
          
Specifies an image in a table, cell, or graph to use as the background.
Specifies whether an image is repeated horizontally, vertically, both, or not repeated.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the image is repeated both horizontally and vertically.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the image is repeated horizontally.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies that the image is repeated vertically.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that the image is not repeated.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to put a scroll bar in the frame that references the body file.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Places a scroll bar in the frame that references the body file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to put a scroll bar in the frame that references the body file.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Places a scroll bar in the frame that references the body file only if needed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BODYSIZE= dimension | dimension% | *] 
          
Specifies the width of the frame that displays the body file in the HTML frame file.

[Syntax: BORDERBOTTOMCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color of the bottom border of the table.
Specifies the line style of the bottom border of the specified cell.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Dashed line
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Dotted line

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BORDERBOTTOMWIDTH=dimension] 
          
Specifies the width of the bottom border of the table.

[Syntax: BORDERCOLOR= color] 
          
Specifies the color of the border in a table or cell if the border is just one color.

[Syntax: BORDERCOLORDARK= color] 
          
In a table or cell , specifies the darker color to use in a border that uses two colors to create 
a three-dimensional effect.

[Syntax: BORDERCOLORLIGHT= color] 
          
In a table or cell, specifies the lighter color to use in a border that uses two colors to create 
a three-dimensional effect.

[Syntax: BORDERLEFTCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color of the left border of the table.
Specifies the line style of the left border of the specified cell.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Dashed line
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Dotted line

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BORDERLEFTWIDTH=dimension] 
          
Specifies the width of the left border of the table.

[Syntax: BORDERRIGHTCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color of the right border of the table.
Specifies the line style of the right border of the selected cell.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Dashed line
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Dotted line

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BORDERRIGHTWIDTH=dimension] 
          
Specifies the width of the right border of the table.

[Syntax: BORDERTOPCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color of the top border of the table.
Specifies the line style of the top border of the specified cell.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Dashed line
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Dotted line

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: BORDERTOPWIDTH=dimension] 
          
Specifies the width of the top border of the table.

[Syntax: BORDERWIDTH= dimension] 
          
Specifies the width of the border of the table.
Specifies the shape of the line at the end of a box whisker.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Serif
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Line

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: CELLPADDING=dimension | dimension%] 
          
Specifies the amount of white space on each of the four sides of the text in a cell in the table.

[Syntax: CELLSPACING=dimension] 
          
Specifies the thickness of the spacing between cells in a table.

[Syntax: CLASS="string"] 
          
Specifies the name of the style sheet class to use in an HTML document for the table or cell.

[Syntax: COLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the color of the foreground in tables, cells, or graphs, which is primarily the color of text.
Specifies the characteristics of a box plot connect line.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Median
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Mean

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the position, within the frame file, of the frames that display the contents and the page files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Places the frames on the left.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Places the frames on the right.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Places the frames at the top.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Places the frames at the bottom.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether to put a scroll bar in the frames in the frame file that display the contents and the page files.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Places a scroll bar in the frames in the frame file that display the contents and the page files.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies not to put a scroll bar in the frames in the frame file that display the contents and the page files.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Whether or not to put a scroll bar in the frames in the frame file that display the contents and the page files should be determined automatically (internally).

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: CONTENTSIZE=dimension | dimension % | *] 
          
Specifies the width of the frames in the frame file that display the contents and the page files.

[Syntax: CONTENTTYPE="string"] 
          
Specifies the value of the content type for pages in an HTML document that is sent directly to a 
web server rather than to a file.

[Syntax: CONTRASTCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the alternate colors for maps. The alternate colors are applied to the blocks on region
areas in block maps.

Specifies the alternate colors for maps. The alternate colors are applied to the blocks on region 
areas in block maps.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Displays caps at the ends of the whiskers.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Displays the line connecting multiple boxes.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Displays filled boxes, bars, ellipses, and bands.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Displays the mean symbol within a box.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Displays the median line within the box

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies whether the drop shadow color for text is displayed.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies that the drop shadow color for text is displayed.
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies that the drop shadow color for text is not displayed.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: ENDCOLOR=color] 
          
Specifies the final color used with a two or three color ramp.

[Syntax: FILLRULEWIDTH= dimension] 
          
Places a rule of the specified width into the space around the text (or entire cell if there is no 
text) in a table where white space would otherwise appear.

[Syntax: FLYOVER="string"] 
          
Specifies the text to show in a data tip for the cell.

[Syntax: FONT=font-definition] 
          
Specifies a font definition to use in tables, cells, and graphs.

[Syntax: FONTFAMILY="string-1<..., string-n>"] 
          
Specifies the font to use in cells and graphs. If you supply multiple fonts, then the destination 
device uses the first one that is installed on the system.

[Syntax: FONTSIZE=dimension | size] 
          
Specifies the size of the font for tables, cells, and graphs.
Specifies the style of the font for tables, cells, and graphs.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Italic font style
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Roman font style
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: In many cases, slant and italic map to the same font.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the font weight of tables, cells, and graphs.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Medium font weight
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Bold font weight

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies the font width of tables, cells, and graphs compared to the width of the usual design of 
the table, cell, or graph.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Normal font width
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Compressed font width

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies the type of frame to use on a table.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: A border at the top
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: A border at the bottom
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Borders at the top, bottom, and both sides
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Borders at the top and bottom

Syntax: PARENT=style-path | PARENT=table-path; ; 
      
Specifies the style/table from which the current style/template inherits from. 

style-path |  table-path
consists of one or more names, separated by periods. Each name represents a directory in a template store.

SAS provides some styles. You can specify one of these styles for style-path, or you can specify a 
user-defined style. These are some of the styles that are currently shipped with SAS:

  styles.default
  styles.beige
  styles.brick
  styles.brown
  styles.d3d
  styles.minimal
  styles.printer
  styles.statdoc

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PAD=dimension | (pad-options)] 
          
Specifies the amount of extra space that is added inside the graph border. The default padding for 
all sides is 10. Values without units are in pixels (px). A unit must be provided if other than pixels.

dimension 
  Specifies a dimension to use for the extra space at the left, right, top, and bottom of the layout border. 

(pad-options) 
  Enables separate settings for the left, right, top, and bottom padding dimensions. Use the pad-options 
  to create non-uniform padding. These options must be enclosed in parentheses. Each option is specified 
  as a name = value pair. Sides not assigned padding are padded with the default amount. 
  Values without units are in pixels (px). A unit must be provided if other than pixels.

  LEFT=dimension 
  specifies the amount of extra space added to the left side. 
  RIGHT=dimension 
  specifies the amount of extra space added to the right side. 
  TOP=dimension 
  specifies the amount of extra space added to the top. 
  BOTTOM=dimension 
  specifies the amount of extra space added to the bottom.
